awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Towards Ubiquitous Sensing With Commodity Wi-Fi
awd_abstract_narration:
The prevalence of Wi-Fi devices and ubiquitous coverage of Wi-Fi networks provide the opportunity to extend Wi-Fi's capabilities beyond communication, particularly in human sensing. As Wi-Fi signals travel through space, they modulate with the human body and undergo wave phenomena such as reflection and diffraction, which carry a rich set of information about the physical environment including human activities and gestures. This project aims to reuse commodity Wi-Fi devices to capture such wave phenomena to sense multiple persons simultaneously and to provide quantifiable gesture recognition. Exploiting commodity Wi-Fi devices for human sensing enables ubiquitous sensing for easy and large-scale deployments without requiring users to wear or install any specialized sensors. The outcome of this project can be directly adopted by industry and will have a societal impact by facilitating a variety of applications such as Human-Computer Interaction, smart home, mobile healthcare, and security surveillance. This project will lead to new technologies for human sensing and provide new insights on developing emerging mobile applications. The research activities will be integrated into Florida State University's Computer Science education program and will include curriculum development, female and minority students involvement, and K-12 education and industry outreach.

This project focuses on building a commodity Wi-Fi based ubiquitous sensing system that can simultaneously sense multiple persons and provides quantifiable gesture recognition without requiring environment-dependent training. The proposed work enables multiple people tracking and activity recognition by extracting the signal reflections from each individual person based on fine-grained signal reflection paths. The periodical change of the reflection signal is further exploited to derive quantitative measures such as the movement distance and speed for quantifiable gesture recognition. Moreover, the motion-induced Doppler effects that reflect the signal dynamic due to human body movements are leveraged to perform environment-independent sensing. Next, it applies the proposed sensing technologies to develop human-computer-interface applications by considering issues such as environmental interferences. In addition, the project expands the Wi-Fi sensing capabilities from human sensing to sensing bio-information of fruit crops. It leverages the frequency diversity to capture the physiological changes of fruit due to ripening and develops mechanisms to extract multipath-independent features for ripeness detection. Finally, the system will be evaluated using real-scale test-beds. The techniques, algorithms, and software resulting from this research will deepen our understanding of mobile sensing and provide practical value by enabling emerging applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project pursues the vision of a system that utilizes prevalence of Wi-Fi devices and ubiquitous coverage of Wi-Fi networks for human sensing. We build a commodity Wi-Fi based ubiquitous sensing system that can simultaneously sense multiple persons and provides quantifiable gesture recognition without requiring environment-dependent training. The system enables multiple people tracking and activity recognition by extracting the signal reflections from each individual person based on fine-grained signal reflection paths. In addition, the system expands the Wi-Fi sensing capabilities from human sensing to sensing smart home objects. Such a Wi-Fi based sensing system enables ubiquitous sensing for easy and large-scale deployments without requiring users to wear or install any specialized sensors.

The system we build advances the techniques in device-free human and object sensing in the following aspects. (1) The system reuses commodity Wi-Fi devices to capture wave phenomena of WiFi signals such as reflection and diffraction to sense multiple persons simultaneously and to provide quantifiable gesture recognition. (2) The periodical change of the reflection signal is further exploited to derive quantitative measures such as the movement distance and speed for quantifiable gesture recognition. (3) The motion-induced Doppler effects that reflect the signal dynamic due to human body movements are leveraged to perform environment-independent sensing.  (4) The frequency diversity is exploited to capture the vibrations of the liquid under different vibration frequency for smart-home object sensing.

Accurately identifying human activities and performing object sensing facilitates a broad range of applications. Exploiting the prevalence of WiFi infrastructures to enable device-free in-home human activity sensing leads to breakthroughs in continuous wellbeing monitoring and smart-home applications without requiring users to wear any radio devices or sensors. This project provides strong evidence of using the commodity WiFi to capture environmental changes for human and object sensing. Major research results have be disseminated to academia and industry through paper presentations and publications in conferences and journals (e.g., MobiCom, MobiSys, SenSys, UbiComp, USENIX Security, and IEEE IoT journal). The project has enabled two graduate students and one faculty member to collaborate with each other and to gain experience with the challenges of building the commodity WiFi sensing systems. The research results have been integrated into both the undergraduate level course "CIS4360 Introduction to Computer Security" and graduate level course "CIS5900 Wireless and Mobile Computing". Moreover, we dismiss and discuss our research findings in the departmental event "CS EXPO" and departmental seminar, where we invite researchers from both academia and industry to give talks about cutting-edge research topics each year. These events enable us to present research findings to students, faculty and experts from industry.
